abstract: Sarah Gellert was becoming shut off from friends and family until UJA-Federation and the Jewish Association for Services for the Aged came to her aid.

abstract: The 72d annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund will end this week with a record total in contributions of more than $2.5 million from about 13,000 donors.    The fund, which conducts an annual campaign on behalf of New York City's destitute residents, was begun by The Times in 1912.
lead_paragraph: The 72d annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund will end this week with a record total in contributions of more than $2.5 million from about 13,000 donors.

abstract: For one woman who couldn’t throw anything out, her apartment became an archaeological study of a life in decline.
snippet: For one woman who couldn’t throw anything out, her apartment became an archaeological study of a life in decline.
lead_paragraph: She simply shut the door. Maybe that would keep everything inside. The debris. The anxieties. The worn furniture. The sadness. The stacks of yellowing papers. The tangle of once-fine clothes. The jumble of interwoven memories of a life past. If she shut the door, it would all be hidden away, and she wouldn’t have to confront It  whatever It was.

abstract: Jordan McKay, 20, turned his back on gangs and a life of drifting from job to job to try to provide a stable home for his 3-year-old daughter.
snippet: Jordan McKay, 20, turned his back on gangs and a life of drifting from job to job to try to provide a stable home for his 3-year-old daughter.
lead_paragraph: Jordan McKay patiently urged his 3-year-old daughter, Skylah, up the malodorous steps to their fifth-floor studio apartment in the Bronx. To calm her from bouncing herky-jerky on her tiny bed, he got a video going, got her a banana. That did it. Soon, in all her blatant cuteness, she was radiating joy. In this way, a day moved forward.

abstract: When she was 5, and when she was 35, it was the writing that pulled her through. As a girl in Brooklyn, a friendly game of hide-and-seek ended abruptly  when a handyman in her building cornered her and demanded that she take off her  clothes. Donna C. dodged his advances, ran back to her apartment and wrote a poem.         As a mother and wife in an abusive marriage, Ms. C. clung to her pen and paper again, scribbling her sorrows in the pages of her journal. In 30 years, she has filled nearly 40 books with poetry and prose and sad songs to herself.
lead_paragraph: When she was 5, and when she was 35, it was the writing that pulled her through. As a girl in Brooklyn, a friendly game of hide-and-seek ended abruptly when a handyman in her building cornered her and demanded that she take off her clothes. Donna C. dodged his advances, ran back to her apartment and wrote a poem.

abstract: A year ago, Elaine Blanco almost became homeless. She lived in a room with her two sons, now 5 and 2, and was planning to move to an apartment with her cousin in Queens. She took the $500 she had for the rent deposit, wrapped it carefully in one of the baby's Pampers and started down Junction Boulevard to pay the landlord.         When she got to the discount store where the landlord worked, she could not find the money. In a panic, she emptied her purse onto the floor and tore into the baby carriage looking for the missing bills.
lead_paragraph: A year ago, Elaine Blanco almost became homeless. She lived in a room with her two sons, now 5 and 2, and was planning to move to an apartment with her cousin in Queens. Ms. Ismailov, 70, a caseworker at the Edith and Carl Marks Jewish Community House of Bensonhurst, Brooklyn, pulled out a booklet of receipts and a manila folder with “Germany” written on it and underlined with a black marker.

abstract: “I read a story in the Neediest Cases, I think it was in January of 2003, about a little boy who had been born without arms and he needed a wheelchair. So I said to my husband, ‘He needs a wheelchair. How much could a wheelchair be?’ Of course, it turned out he needed a big wheelchair, and a very complicated one, because he had to work it with his shoulders. It took a long time. It went on and on, and finally I said, ‘I want to meet him.’ ”.
snippet: “I read a story in the Neediest Cases, I think it was in January of 2003, about a little boy who had been born without arms and he needed a wheelchair. So I said to my husband, ‘He needs a wheelchair. How much could a wheelchair be?’ Of course, it...

So I said to my husband, ‘He needs a wheelchair. How much could a wheelchair be?’ Of course, it turned out he needed a big wheelchair, and a very complicated one, because he had to work it with his shoulders. It took a long time. It went on and on, and finally I said, ‘I want to meet him.’ ” - Kathy Greenberg, Manhattan

headline.print_headline: When Money Is Just a First Step

abstract: With reconstruction about to begin, funds from the Neediest Cases helps a woman move to temporary housing.
snippet: With reconstruction about to begin, funds from the Neediest Cases helps a woman move to temporary housing.
lead_paragraph: On the night of Oct. 29, 2012, Linda Vergara looked out the front door of her home in Gerritsen Beach, Brooklyn, and thought: “This is not good. We better get out of here.” Hurricane Sandy had arrived a few hours earlier, and Ms. Vergara, like thousands of New Yorkers, assumed she was in a safe zone and would not need to evacuate. Then the surge came. By the time she got her coat on and headed out to the street, the water was up to her waist. She saw cars and other debris floating around and joined some of her neighbors as they struggled to reach higher ground.

headline.main: Still Recovering From Hurricane Sandy
headline.print_headline: Still Recovering From Hurricane Sandy

lead_paragraph: The morning of March 31, 2009, is stamped on Jose Perez’s brain. He woke up with stabbing pains in his legs. His wife called an ambulance, and he was taken to Staten Island University Hospital. A nurse ran a blood test. Half an hour later, five doctors walked into his room.

lead_paragraph: Juan Galarza peered into Tammy Rodriguez’s obsidian eyes for the first time in a stairwell at a technical school in Manhattan in 1986. He fell madly, passionately in love. They felt rich, despite the little money in their bank accounts, and promised their devotion in marriage three years later.

abstract: A woman enduring physical hardships and a roach infestation gets some help so she can focus on her goals.
snippet: A woman enduring physical hardships and a roach infestation gets some help so she can focus on her goals.
lead_paragraph: At first, Carmen Caraballo saw the roaches scurrying across the floor of her $591-a-month apartment in the Bronx, and then onto the kitchen counter.

headline.main: Skirmishing With Roaches, and Fighting Back Against Bigger Foes
headline.print_headline: Skirmishing With Roaches, and Fighting Back Against Bigger Foes

abstract: It’s a challenge for Priscilla Leontitsis, a musician, to care for her husband, Nicolas, who has multiple sclerosis, but she said: “I’m 77. I’m able to work.”
snippet: It’s a challenge for Priscilla Leontitsis, a musician, to care for her husband, Nicolas, who has multiple sclerosis, but she said: “I’m 77. I’m able to work.”
lead_paragraph: Priscilla Leontitsis first spotted her future husband, Nicolas, in 1989 at Oasis, a Greek restaurant in White Plains that he owned. She was a local choir director and soprano, and she had stopped in for dinner.

headline.main: A Husband’s Chronic Illness Changes a Couple’s Life
headline.print_headline: A Husband’s Chronic Illness Changes a Couple’s Life

abstract: Mariama Toe became “a master of packing my stuff” in her youth, which included a stint in foster care. But the support of a mother figure has emboldened her to go to college.
snippet: Mariama Toe became “a master of packing my stuff” in her youth, which included a stint in foster care. But the support of a mother figure has emboldened her to go to college.
lead_paragraph: Pulling up stakes and leaving behind family have been recurring themes in Mariama Toe’s life.

headline.main: Bumped From Home to Home, Then ‘Pushed’ Into College
headline.print_headline: A Rootless Existence, Then a Helpful Push Into Higher Education

abstract: For Shaniqua Freeman, a 31-year-old with cerebral palsy, moving into her own apartment was a symbol that she was an independent adult.
snippet: For Shaniqua Freeman, a 31-year-old with cerebral palsy, moving into her own apartment was a symbol that she was an independent adult.
lead_paragraph: It was a mix of shock and utter disbelief for Shaniqua Freeman when she unlocked the deadbolt on the door of her first apartment and slowly moved her wheelchair into the living room.

headline.main: Finding Independence, Despite a Disability
headline.print_headline: Finding Independence, Despite a Disability
